conclusion: To calculate the work done by the gas on the surroundings during the cyclic process, we need to analyze the pressure-volume (P-V) diagram provided.
The work done in a cyclic process is equal to the area enclosed by the cycle on the P-V diagram.
The P-V diagram shows a triangular cycle with vertices at points A, B, and C.
Point A: P = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V = 2 L
Point B: P = 4 x 10^5 Pa, V = 2 L
Point C: P = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V = 5 L
The cycle involves three processes: A → B: Vertical line (constant volume, V = 2 L).
The cycle involves three processes: B → C: Diagonal line (changing pressure and volume).
The cycle involves three processes: C → A: Horizontal line (constant pressure, P = 1 x 10^5 Pa).
The work done by the gas is calculated as: W = ∫ P dV.
A → B: No change in volume (dV = 0), so W = 0.
B → C: Work done is represented by the area under the diagonal line. This will be calculated as part of the triangular area.
C → A: Constant pressure process (P = 1 x 10^5 Pa), and the change in volume is ΔV = V_final - V_initial = 2 L → 5 L = 3 L = 3 x 10^-3 m^3.
Work done: W = P ΔV = (1 x 10^5) x (3 x 10^-3) = 300 J.
The total work done in the cyclic process is equal to the area enclosed by the triangle on the P-V diagram.
Height: P_B - P_A = 4 x 10^5 Pa - 1 x 10^5 Pa = 3 x 10^5 Pa.
The area of the triangle is: Area = 1/2 x Base x Height.
